content:
I suggest replacing figure 3 of the paper, which only gives one chain (and is missing 3102 between 270 and 3) by longest_implication_chain.pdf, with source file longest_implication_chain.tex, which gives all longest chains up to duality (the parts above and below the dashed line can be dualized independently).

For reference, longest chains from law 2 to law 3 to law 1

2 → 4 → 1037 → 1237 → 103 → 1027 → 9 → 418 → 48 → 412 → 3
2 → 4 → 1037 → 1237 → 103 → 1027 → 9 → 618 → 48 → 412 → 3
2 → 4 → 1037 → 1237 → 103 → 1033 → 9 → 418 → 48 → 412 → 3
2 → 4 → 1037 → 1237 → 103 → 1033 → 9 → 618 → 48 → 412 → 3
2 → 4 → 1037 → 1237 → 103 → 824 → 9 → 418 → 48 → 412 → 3
2 → 4 → 1037 → 1237 → 103 → 824 → 9 → 618 → 48 → 412 → 3
2 → 4 → 1037 → 1237 → 103 → 829 → 9 → 418 → 48 → 412 → 3
2 → 4 → 1037 → 1237 → 103 → 829 → 9 → 618 → 48 → 412 → 3
2 → 4 → 1037 → 1237 → 1235 → 824 → 9 → 418 → 48 → 412 → 3
2 → 4 → 1037 → 1237 → 1235 → 824 → 9 → 618 → 48 → 412 → 3
2 → 5 → 2499 → 2415 → 2381 → 2716 → 28 → 2973 → 270 → 3102 → 3
2 → 5 → 2499 → 2415 → 2381 → 2716 → 28 → 3122 → 270 → 3102 → 3
2 → 5 → 2499 → 2415 → 238 → 2716 → 28 → 2973 → 270 → 3102 → 3
2 → 5 → 2499 → 2415 → 238 → 2716 → 28 → 3122 → 270 → 3102 → 3
2 → 5 → 2499 → 2415 → 238 → 2787 → 28 → 2973 → 270 → 3102 → 3
2 → 5 → 2499 → 2415 → 238 → 2787 → 28 → 3122 → 270 → 3102 → 3
2 → 5 → 2499 → 2415 → 238 → 2513 → 28 → 2973 → 270 → 3102 → 3
2 → 5 → 2499 → 2415 → 238 → 2513 → 28 → 3122 → 270 → 3102 → 3
2 → 5 → 2499 → 2415 → 238 → 2550 → 28 → 2973 → 270 → 3102 → 3
2 → 5 → 2499 → 2415 → 238 → 2550 → 28 → 3122 → 270 → 3102 → 3
3 → 3715 → 326 → 3522 → 3456 → 1
3 → 3715 → 326 → 307 → 3253 → 1
3 → 3715 → 326 → 3319 → 3253 → 1
3 → 3715 → 375 → 3915 → 3862 → 1
3 → 3715 → 375 → 4118 → 4065 → 1
3 → 3715 → 375 → 359 → 4065 → 1

I got the list of chains with a script longest_implication_chain.py based on python's networkx package. When restricting to laws of order 3 and lower, the longest chain 2→4→103→9→48→3→326→307→1 is simply a subchain of one of the above, so this is not just an artifact of our cutoff. This part of the implication graph is really "denser" in some way.
Sounds good to me. Can you submit a PR for this?
Bruno Le Floch has marked this topic as resolved.
